content.heading: HTML Form Attributes
paragraphs: This chapter describes the different attributes for the HTML <form> element.

content.heading: The Action Attribute
paragraphs: The action attribute defines the action to be performed when the form is submitted. Usually, the form data is sent to a file on the server when the user clicks the submit button.

content.heading: Example
The Target Attribute
paragraphs: The target attribute specifies where to display the response received after submitting the form. The target attribute can have one of several values.

content.heading: Example
The Method Attribute
paragraphs: The method attribute specifies the HTTP method to be used when submitting the form data. The form-data can be sent as URL variables (with method="get") or as an HTTP POST transaction (with method="post").

content.heading: Example
The Autocomplete Attribute
paragraphs: The autocomplete attribute specifies whether a form should have autocomplete on or off. When autocomplete is on, the browser automatically completes values based on previously entered data.

content.heading: Example
The Novalidate Attribute
paragraphs: The novalidate attribute is a boolean attribute that specifies that the form data should not be validated when submitted.
